persona.name: Sharon Louise Keller

occupation.title: Retired / part-time childcare aide and seasonal cashier
occupation.organization: Formerly: Maple Lane Grocery (part-time cashier for 20 years). Currently: volunteers and does part-time, short shifts at local daycare/church nursery and seasonal cashier work during holidays.
occupation.description: Sharon is officially retired and lives on Social Security and small retirement savings, but supplements income with short, low-demand shifts: occasional mornings at the church nursery, two afternoons a week as a paid aide in a neighbor-run daycare, and holiday cashier work at the local grocery. Her responsibilities are practical and people-facing: supervising toddlers, preparing simple snacks, changing diapers, folding laundry, light cleaning, checking out customers, and chatting with regulars. She is trusted for being dependable in short, repetitive tasks, for her patience with young children, and for her ability to calm upset kids. She does not handle heavy lifting or complex finances at work. Skills used on the job include basic first aid/CPR (renewed sporadically), reading children’s books aloud, and simple record-keeping for the daycare (attendance sheets, medication logs).

persona.residence: Applewood Township, Minnesota, USA (suburban small town)
persona.education: High school diploma; attended community college courses intermittently in early adulthood (child development and bookkeeping certificates, no completed degree). Completed a short certificate in basic childcare from a local community center 10 years ago.
long_term_goals: Provide a stable, loving home and wholesome upbringing for the two young children she now cares for (ages 5 and 3).
Maintain independence as long as possible despite mobility limitations and chronic health conditions.
Ensure that the children have access to education and opportunities she did not have (save for community college classes).
Leave the house and a small nest egg to the children or a trusted relative after her death.
Stay engaged in the local community (church, town meetings) and pass on local traditions to the children (holidays, Sunday dinners).
Keep her marriage to her husband steady and supportive through shared caregiving.
Learn simple modern tech tasks (video calls, smartphone photos, online bill pay) well enough to help the children and stay connected with extended family.
Age with dignity: avoid institutional care if possible and organize in-home support if needed.
Teach basic life skills and thriftiness to the children: cooking simple meals, gardening, recycling and making do.
Make a modest trip to see an old friend in a nearby state once health permits.

style.speech_and_tone: Warm, folksy Midwestern cadence with a soft Minnesota/upper Midwest twang; uses colloquial diminutives ('hon', 'sweetie', 'darlin') when addressing children and friends. Generally conversational, not formal, with a tendency to repeat important points slowly when speaking to strangers or on the phone.
style.mannerisms: Tends to pause and look down when searching for a word; smiles with a slight head tilt; often folds her hands in front of her; laughs with a small, wheezy chuckle when something amuses her. Uses phrases like 'you betcha' occasionally, and often references local weather or church events. Has a habit of patting her pockets to ensure she has phone/keys.
style.formality: Informal in daily interactions; more reserved and polite in civic or medical settings. Prefers face-to-face conversations and keeps phone calls short. When stressed she becomes laconic and more rule-focused.
style.physical_presentation: Practical dresser: layered knit cardigans, elastic-waist trousers, orthopedic shoes. Keeps hair in a short perm-style bob, usually gray with streaks of remaining blonde. Wears reading glasses on a chain and an inexpensive hearing aid in one ear.
style.digital_style: Reluctant but competent with smartphones — uses large-button mode, keeps few apps (phone, weather, a simple photo app, occasional video call). Prefers paper notices, hand-written lists, and a physical calendar on the fridge. Asks grandchildren or neighbors to show her things on screens rather than trying to figure it out alone.
style.interaction_preference: Comfortable with small talk, remembers neighborhood gossip and personal details about many residents; patient with children, polite with officials, and cordial but blunt with bill collectors or service workers when necessary.

traits: Dependable: others can count on her to be at appointments and to help with childcare on short notice.
Nurturing: instinctively attentive to children’s emotional and physical needs; often puts others' comfort before her own.
Frugal/practical: careful with money, resourceful in the kitchen and home maintenance, dislikes waste.
Stubborn: holds firm on traditional values and routines; resistant to rapid change.
Gregarious in small circles: enjoys regulars at church and grocery store but not large, unfamiliar crowds.
Anxious about health and finances: worries about bills, falls, and the children's future.
Loyal: long friendships and a marriage that has lasted decades, values commitments.
Sentimental: keeps old letters, photographs and holiday decorations; shares stories often.
Slow to trust new institutions: wary of bureaucracies and skeptical of complex social programs.
Humorous in a dry, self-deprecating way: cracks jokes about aging, bad knees, and small-town life.
Resourceful in crises: can improvise childcare, whipping up a snack or soothing a cut with what’s on hand.
Modest: dislikes being the center of attention and downplays achievements.

big_five.openness: Low (28/100). Prefers familiar routines and traditional ideas; not highly experimental, though open to small, practical innovations that help daily life.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (78/100). Reliable, punctual, orderly in household matters, careful with medication schedules, and good at maintaining routines for the children.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-Low (42/100). Friendly and chatty with acquaintances and neighbors, but finds large social gatherings tiring and prefers small groups.
big_five.agreeableness: High (74/100). Helpful, cooperative, and trusting toward people she knows; can be blunt or stubborn when she feels wronged.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High (64/100). Prone to worry about health, finances, and the children's welfare; has moments of low mood and anxiety, especially when medical appointments or bills pile up.

general_interests: Spending time with the two young children (reading bedtime stories, simple crafts, baking).
Attending the local church and participating in social gatherings there.
Gardening modestly: tomatoes, herbs, and window boxes of flowers.
Watching daytime television soaps and local news.
Listening to older country and folk music (Patsy Cline, Johnny Cash, John Denver).
Cooking simple, traditional meals: meatloaf, stews, casseroles, apple pie.
Thrifting and yard-sale shopping for bargains and vintage kitchenware.
Knitting simple scarves and baby blankets.
Baking for neighbors and church potlucks.
Walking short distances around the neighborhood when weather allows.

favorite_breakfasts: Warm oatmeal with brown sugar and sliced banana.
Toast with margarine and coffee (light roast, cream, one sugar).
Occasional scrambled eggs when she has more energy.
favorite_snacks: Cheddar on crackers for a quick bite.
beverages: Black drip coffee in the morning, decaf in the early afternoon.
Occasional diet soda when on sale.
dislikes: Exotic or spicy cuisines (too strong for the grandchildren).
Overly processed convenience foods for regular meals.

tv_shows: Local evening news (prefers short, familiar anchors).
Public television cooking and gardening segments.
music_preferences: Hums hymns from church services often.
Radio mornings for oldies and community announcements.
books: Library books on parenting and children’s picture books.
Light historical fiction (prefers clear narratives and happy endings).

social_style: Prefers frequent, short visits from neighbors and relatives over long distant trips.
Enjoys having other children over for safe, supervised playdates.
Appreciates when friends bring over a casserole or help with snow shoveling.

vacation_preferences.overview: Short, local, family-centered vacations are preferred. Long flights and complicated itineraries are avoided due to mobility, health, budget, and childcare logistics. Prioritizes child safety, comfort, and familiar routines during travel.
preferred_types: Short car trips within 2-3 hours' drive (lakeside cabin, relatives’ homes in-state).
Renting a single-level accessible cabin for a long weekend with a small kitchen to cook familiar meals.
Driving to a family-friendly state park with paved paths and accessible picnic areas.
Day trips to local attractions: children’s museum nearby, small zoo, community pool.
accommodation_preferences: Single-level lodgings or ground-floor hotel rooms (no stairs) with accessible bathroom.
Places that allow a travel crib/pack-n-play and have a small kitchenette.
Vacation rentals where she can prepare simple meals to avoid expensive eating out.
child-centered_details: Brings the children’s own bedding and favorite stuffed animals to help them sleep well away from home.
Plans nap times into day itineraries and avoids late-night events.
Prefers destinations with playgrounds, shallow wading areas, or supervised kids’ activity centers.
Carries a compact stroller, portable booster seat, and extra snacks for stops.
Chooses destinations with short driving segments and frequent rest stops.
Avoids flights longer than 3 hours due to anxiety about mobility and needing assistance with boarding.
Prefers to travel with a support adult (her husband or an adult daughter/neighbor) who can manage lifting and fast movement when needed.
Tends to pack a small first-aid kit, extra diapers/wipes, children's medication, and written emergency contacts.
Seeks out community pools or shallow beach areas rather than deep-water swimming for safety.
Schedules vacations around local events (county fair) that are family-friendly and low-cost.
budget_and_logistics: Uses coupons, AAA discounts, and senior discounts wherever possible.
Avoids expensive resort packages; favors modest lodgings and potluck-style meals.
Prefers weekends and off-peak times to avoid crowds and save money.
Carries printed directions and a paper list in case phone battery dies.

shopping_and_consumption: Favors local grocery stores and cooperative buying for staples.
Buys generics and store brands; watches coupons and weekly ads.
Enjoys occasional small impulse buys at thrift stores for children’s toys or kitchen items.
Tends to repair appliances and clothing rather than immediately replace them.
technology_preferences: Uses a simple smartphone with big icons primarily for calls and photos.
Likes video calls for seeing distant family but needs help setting them up.
Reads printed newspapers and community flyers rather than relying on social media.
Reluctant to share personal data online; wary of digital-only services for bill pay.

beliefs: Family is the central organizing principle of life: children, spouse, and extended family come first.
Children should be raised with routines, clear boundaries, and plenty of affection.
Hard work and thrift will see you through difficult times.
Neighbors should look out for one another in small towns; community ties matter.
Church involvement fosters moral grounding and social support.
Older people still have value and can offer childcare and wisdom.
Healthcare is important, but one should be practical about costs and avoid overusing specialists.
Vaccinations for children are necessary and helpful, though she worries about side effects and prefers trusted local doctors.
Government assistance is useful for people in need but can be bureaucratic and hard to navigate.
Public schools are generally a good foundation, but parental involvement matters more than fancy programs.
Young children need lots of outdoor, unstructured play rather than screens.
Debt should be minimized; better to live modestly than to accumulate loans.
Respect for elders and modesty are positive traits to teach children.
Discipline should be firm but loving; spanking is not her first choice but she believes in consequences.
Marriage vows should be honored; she values stability even when it’s difficult.
Neighbors and family should help each other in times of emergency; mutual aid is practical.
Technology is useful but overwhelming; rely on simple tools you understand.
Local stores and small businesses deserve support over large chains when possible.
Environmental stewardship is good in small ways: recycling, conserving water, and not wasting food.
Government should provide basic safety nets for seniors and vulnerable children.
People age differently; many stereotypes about aging are unfair and hurtful.
Doctors should be listened to, but patients should ask questions and advocate for themselves.
Teachers are underpaid and undervalued; community should support schools through volunteering.
It’s better to be known as a helpful neighbor than to be praised nationally.
Loneliness is a public health issue among older adults and caregivers.
Nutrition and modest exercise (walking, gardening) help manage chronic conditions.
Trust is built slowly; people who gossip or break promises are avoided.
Children should learn practical skills early—cooking, folding laundry, simple money management.
Safety (car seats, watchful supervision) is more important than convenience when caring for children.
Small pleasures—coffee with a friend, a well-baked pie—are worth prioritizing.
A good night's sleep is underrated; try to protect children's and her own sleep schedules.
Medication adherence is non-negotiable; missing doses leads to problems.
Elected officials should be approachable and responsive to local needs.
Geriatric care and accessible housing are underfunded and need advocacy.
Volunteerism is rewarding and a practical way to contribute even with limited funds.
People should plan for emergencies (power outage, winter storms) with basic supplies and a plan.
skills: Experienced childcare and toddler supervision: diapering, bathing, soothing, feeding, nap routines.
Basic first aid and infant/child CPR certification (renewed in the past but may be due again).
Food preparation and economical meal planning: can stretch groceries into multiple meals and prepare child-friendly options.
Household management: laundry, cleaning, scheduling appointments, coordinating school/daycare drop-offs.
Light gardening and seasonal yard care: can grow tomatoes, herbs, and maintain window boxes.
Basic sewing and mending: can fix buttons, hem pants, and knit simple baby blankets.
Simple bookkeeping: paying bills, balancing a checkbook, following a cash budget.
Driving short distances safely, familiar with local roads and routes to school and pediatrician.
Comforting and de-escalation techniques for upset children: distraction, breathing exercises, songs.
Organizational skills: maintains a visible family calendar with appointments, activities, and medication times.
Medication management: organizes daily pill box and follows dosing schedules for chronic conditions.
Low-tech problem solving: uses duct tape, glue, or simple fixes to keep toys and appliances working.
Community networking: can call neighbors, church volunteers, or relatives to arrange temporary help.
Basic computer literacy: can read email, use a calendar app with assistance, display photos on a tablet.
Advocacy for grandchildren/wards at school meetings: speaks up calmly and persuasively for children's needs.

general: Checks the children's rooms and doors before bed even if confident they're asleep.
Keeps a paper grocery list on the fridge and clips coupons weekly.
Greets neighbors by name and asks after their families.
Hums hymns when folding laundry or baking.
Prefers face-to-face talk but accepts phone calls for quick matters.
Is more likely to say yes to favors than to ask for help.
Gets anxious before medical appointments and prepares lists of questions for doctors.
Remembers holidays, birthdays, and anniversaries and sends handwritten cards.
Protective about the children's routines: avoids last-minute scheduling.

morning: Wakes at 6:00 AM most days; checks blood pressure and takes morning medications.
Prepares breakfast for household and brews coffee.
Gets the children dressed, prepares a simple packed snack, and checks the diaper bag.
Does a quick sweep of refrigerator and cupboards to plan the day's meals.
daytime: Spends mornings on light household chores and short walks if arthritis allows.
Alternates between supervised play and quiet reading/TV time for the children.
Runs errands mid-morning to avoid crowds, uses a small list to conserve energy.
Attends part-time shifts (nursery/daycare) two or three days a week; volunteers at church potlucks when possible.
evening: Makes a home-cooked dinner (often a casserole or soup).
Baths the younger child before a predictable bedtime routine: story, lullaby, lights out.
Spends 30 minutes catching up on bills, writing notes, or knitting.
Takes evening pills, watches local news, and goes to bed around 10:00 PM.
weekend: Attends church on Sundays, participates in fellowship lunch occasionally.
Visits a farmer’s market or small thrift stores on Saturdays when the children are with a neighbor or family member.
Has one extended family visit per month or a potluck with neighbors and brings homemade baked goods.

communication_style: Direct but kind: speaks plainly about needs and expectations.
Uses short stories or proverbs to make a point when advising younger family members.
Likes to follow up in person rather than through text for important matters.

health.summary: Chronic conditions with mobility limitation; manages multiple prescriptions and uses aids. Generally stable but requires regular monitoring.
conditions: Osteoarthritis in knees and hips causing limited mobility and occasional joint pain; uses a cane for longer walks.
Hypertension controlled with daily medication (ACE inhibitor).
Type 2 diabetes managed through diet, metformin, and blood-glucose checks (non-insulin).
Mild hearing loss (uses one hearing aid in the right ear).
Early-stage macular degeneration requiring regular ophthalmology follow-ups; uses reading glasses.
History of a low-impact fall two years ago leading to increased caution; no major fractures.
Mild clinical anxiety related to health and caregiving responsibilities; sees a primary care clinician for discussion and occasionally uses short-term anxiolytic medication.
mobility_and_aids: Uses a single-point cane around the house and outdoors when surfaces are uneven.
Has handrails installed by the front/back steps and grab bars in the main bathroom (installed after the fall).
Prefers single-level house layout; bedrooms and main living areas are on the first floor.
Has a reachable list of local taxi/neighbor contacts for emergency rides if husband is unavailable.
medication_management: Organizes medications in a weekly pill organizer; spouse double-checks once a week.
Keeps a medication list in the wallet and on the fridge for emergency clinic visits.
mental_health: Occasional low mood and worry; stays socially engaged through church and neighbors which provides buffer.
Uses faith, prayer, and neighborly chats as coping strategies; has been open to counseling when recommended.
Occasional sleepless nights worrying about the children's future or unexpected bills.
healthcare_access: Sees a primary care physician every 3 months for chronic disease management.
Children see a local pediatric clinic with sliding-scale fees when necessary.
Has Medicaid/Medicare coverage supplemented by small retirement savings; still worries about co-pays and dental costs.

relationships.name: Robert Keller
relationships.description: Married 45 years. Quiet, practical, retired city maintenance worker. Assists with lifting and outdoor chores but has his own health issues (mild COPD). Extremely supportive emotionally; they share caregiving duties for the young children. He is less comfortable with paperwork and online systems, so Sharon usually handles logistics.

relationships.name: Emma Grace Keller
relationships.description: Energetic, beginning kindergarten. Favorite activities: drawing, playing with dolls, watching ‘Mister Rogers’-style shows. Has a simple asthma diagnosis managed with an inhaler kept at home and school. Sharon is the primary caregiver and advocates for her at school meetings.

relationships.name: Benjamin 'Ben' Keller
relationships.description: Outgoing toddler who loves trains and snack-time. Not yet potty-trained consistently; Sharon handles most of the nighttime care. Needs regular naps; Sharon carefully plans daily routines.

relationships.name: Lisa Monroe
relationships.description: Sharon's middle child who passed away two years ago; Sharon and Robert took guardianship of Lisa's two children. Sharon frequently mentions Lisa and keeps her photographs prominently displayed. The loss shaped Sharon's recent choices to focus intensely on the grandchildren's well-being.

relationships.name: Tom Keller
relationships.description: Lives two hours away; reliable but busy. Visits monthly and helps with heavier tasks (snow removal, major repairs). Calls weekly to check on bills and the grandchildren.
relationships.relationship_quality: Supportive, practical; sometimes tension about long-term guardianship planning and finances.

relationships.name: Margaret 'Peg' Halloway
relationships.description: Weekly coffee buddy; helps with rides and small child-related favors. Church friend and key emotional support.

relationships.name: Local church community
relationships.description: Active participant in Sunday services, potlucks, and occasional childcare swaps. Provides occasional financial and meal support when needed.

relationships.name: Pediatric nurse (clinic)
relationships.description: Familiar healthcare contact at the children's clinic, acts as a trusted resource for vaccinations, asthma care, and questions about developmental milestones.

relationships.name: Social worker (county)
relationships.description: Intermittent contact due to guardianship paperwork and benefits; Sharon is wary but cooperative with this person.

other_facts: Sharon was born and raised in a small town in central Minnesota; childhood included large family dinners and church picnics.
She met Robert at a county dance when she was 19; they married at 23 and have been together since, weathering lean years and a few relocations for work.
Worked 20 years as a part-time grocery cashier while raising children, which allowed flexible hours but limited retirement savings.
Has a strong relationship with the children’s school principal who admires her dedication.
Kept a leather-bound recipe book of family dishes, with notes in the margins from her mother and grandmother.
Keeps a shoebox of letters from her late daughter Lisa and reads them quietly when feeling blue.
Once ran a church bake sale that raised funds to repair the town hall roof; she is proud of that.
Has a faded High School Class of 1973 yearbook with many notes from old friends.
Loves holiday traditions: Thanksgiving is always at her house with a modest feast and multiple pies.
Her home is paid off; the couple saved and paid the mortgage years ago, which provides them security despite low yearly income.
She occasionally sells small knitted items at the church bazaar for extra pocket money.
Is an avid user of the county library and brings the children to the story hour every week.
Keeps a small vegetable patch in the backyard and shares tomatoes with neighbors in late summer.
Has a ritual of writing bills due on a yellow legal pad and circling urgent items in red.
Has a slight penmanship quirk: writes in neat, compact cursive inherited from her mother.
Once spent a summer working as a nanny for a family across the state which deepened her confidence with infants.
Is the family historian: she keeps photo albums labeled with years and small stories about each picture.
Has a favorite recipe for cinnamon rolls that she bakes for church and neighborhood breakfasts.
Avoids winter travel unless essential; the combination of ice, mobility issues, and caregiving logistics makes it risky.
Has a list of emergency phone numbers taped to the kitchen cabinet: pediatric clinic, neighbor, son Tom, local fire department.
Has kept a faithful small savings account after years of pinching pennies; uses it only for car repairs or medical co-pays.
Uses a small notebook to capture funny things the children say and hopes to someday give it to them as a keepsake.
Enjoys simple crafts with the kids: pasta necklaces, finger painting, and making holiday ornaments.
Hosts a monthly 'soup and a story' gathering for neighborhood seniors and young parents to bridge generations.
Has recurring nightmares about being unable to find the children; wakes up checking the house.
Knows many neighbors’ birthdays and shows up with pie or cookies without being asked.
Once organized a small neighborhood effort to shovel for an elderly couple after a big snow; it became an annual tradition.
Her hearing aid battery tends to die at inopportune times; she keeps spares in the glove compartment.
Is nervous around technology scams and has been targeted by phone scams twice; now screens calls and asks neighbors for help.
Has a longtime fear of being a burden on her children, which motivates her thriftiness and willingness to keep working part-time.
Keeps a dated but reliable mini-van with booster seats and a lot of duct-tape repairs; it’s been essential for pediatric appointments and trips.
Has kept a small collection of vintage teacups inherited from her grandmother; uses them on special Sunday guests.
Remembers names and small personal details about nearly everyone at the grocery store which makes her well-liked by staff.
Has a modest will that names her husband as primary guardian and her eldest son Tom as successor guardian for the children; she worries about this and sometimes calls Tom to confirm arrangements.
Has once been denied an accessible ramp at a rented vacation cabin and now always calls ahead to confirm accessibility before booking.
Keeps a 'comfort box' for storm nights: batteries, a flashlight, children's favorite small toys, nonperishable snacks, and a warm blanket.
Has an ongoing project to digitize old family photographs with the help of her son when he visits.
Celebrates small wins publicly: if a child uses the potty, she posts an upbeat note in the family group chat and calls proud relatives.
Knits a special baby blanket for each new member of the extended family; the children's blankets are labeled with their names and dates.
